sections.text:
This paper presents a speculative scenario for the evolution of the earth’s surface environment and biological community 3.5–2.4 Ga based on the geologic record and its interpretation. Available geologic evidence suggests that the earth’s climate before 3.2 Ga was hot, probably 60–73 ◦C, as a result of a CO2 and CH4 greenhouse. The early biological community was probably dominated by anoxygenic photosynthetic thermophiles. Cyanobacteria, if they evolved before 3.1 Ga, would have struggled to survive at such high temperatures. As a result, the atmosphere contained extremely low levels of O2 and Δ33S shows wide departures from 0 indicating mass independent fractionation of S isotopes in the upper atmosphere. This hot early climate collapsed 3.1–3.0 Ga due to growth of large new blocks of continental crust (cratons), the weathering of which resulted in the depletion of atmospheric CO2 and eventual drawdown of CH4 due to formation and rainout of methane aerosols. Cooling may have culminated in glaciation about 3.0–2.9 Ga. This climatic catastrophe and attendant changes in atmospheric composition drove a major biological revolution 3.0–2.7 Ga characterized by the emergence of new low-temperature taxa, including cyanobacteria, and their spread throughout surface environments at the expense of extreme thermophiles, including methanogens. During a period of general tectonic stability, 3.0–2.7 Ga, the earth’s surface was characterized by overall clement conditions with temperatures <60 ◦C, abundant cyanobacteria and the formation of associated three-dimensional stromatolites, and a mild oxygenation of the atmosphere and attendant reduction in mass independent fractionation. As the cratons that had formed 3.1–3.0 Ga were eroded down and gradually covered by sediments, tectonic recycling and a burst of new greenstone-belt volcanism began to increase atmospheric CO2 after 2.75 Ga and by 2.7 Ga surface temperatures had returned to >60 ◦C. Cyanobacteria were again suppressed, O2 production waned, and atmospheric mass independent fractionation is again indicated by extreme variations in Δ33S. These conditions persisted, perhaps intermittently, until about 2.5–2.4 Ga, when weathering and erosion of vast new blocks of continental crust formed about 2.65–2.6 Ga caused the second, and probably last collapse of a >60 ◦C surface climate. Broad tectonic, climatic, and biological events 3.5–2.9 Ga are remarkably parallel to those of the Late Archean and Paleoproterozoic 2.75–2.2 Ga and Neoproterozoic 1.0–0.50 Ga. These ∼500-myr long cycles of greenstone volcanism and crustal generation; climatic and atmospheric instability; and biological innovation reflect the long-term interaction of the tectonic, atmospheric, climatic, and biological components of the earth’s surface system. They suggest that the evolution of the earth’s interior, expressed through its control on the formation of large blocks of continental crust, has influenced atmospheric composition and climate which in turn have provided a fundamental control on the timing and directions of biological evolution throughout earth history. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The 3.5–2.5 Ga geologic record has come under increasing scrutiny in recent years as it has become apparent that a number of major geological, biological, and environmental events during this interval may have marked the beginning of the transition from a fundamentally different young Hadean and early Paleoarchean earth to a more modern Proterozoic and ultimately Phanerozoic world. These events appear to have included the formation of the first large stable cratons, evolution of several major biological groups, and global climate and atmospheric changes, possibly including transitions from a hot young earth to a more temperate or even cold climate and the initial stages of oxygenation of the atmosphere. The objective of the present discussion is to evaluate the geologic record of this interval in order to better understand these events and their possible relationships to one another.
The discussion covers a broad spectrum of processes and events in the very distant, dimly viewed past from the generation of continental crust and formation of cratons to atmospheric and climatic change to biological evolution. The interpretation of these events, and in many cases the events themselves, are controversial and our analysis here is necessarily brief and speculative at many points. However, we feel that there is an internally consistent set of observations and interpretations that help to link tectonic, atmospheric, climatic, and biological events over this interval of time. We are not the first to recognize these relationships. From early modern discussions of the relationships between crustal and sedimentary evolution (Veizer and Jansen, 1979, 1985; Taylor and McLennan, 1985) to early suggestions of the more complex interrelationships among crust, atmosphere, and ocean evolution (Lowe, 1992, 1994b; Des Marais, 1994; Carver and Vardavas, 1994, 1995) to modern efforts to link the evolution of the crust, atmosphere, climate, ocean, and life (Schwartzman, 1999; Bekker et al., 2001; Lindsay and Brasier, 2002; Tice and Lowe, 2004), there has been a continuing effort to develop synthetic, integrated pictures of the evolution of the earth’s surface system. While we have sought to include as many of the critical literature references as possible, the sheer number has made it impossible to acknowledge all of the significant contributions and we apologize in advance to any authors of key papers that we have inadvertently missed or left out.
The preserved geologic record itself makes clarification and comparisons of events during this 1 billion year long interval difficult. The record of geologic events before 3.0 Ga lies solely within greenstone belt

sequences, all of which are heavily deformed and metasomatically altered and most of which are sheared and metamorphosed. These volcanic-sedimentary assemblages occur as remnants within younger craton basement terrains and provide a record of volcanism, sedimentation, and associated tonalite-trondhjemitegranodiorite (TTG) plutonism that culminated in the formation and stabilization of the cratons of which they are a part. They record life and surface environments on unstable volcanic surfaces subject to rapid subsidence, magmatic inflation, burial beneath thick volcanic flows, and blanketing by layers of pyroclastic debris. The culminating stages in the evolution of these belts involved deformation, uplift, and sedimentation in and around orogenic highlands. There are as yet no known lcratons that formed before 3.1 Ga and no corresponding unambiguous pre-3.1 Ga craton cover or craton margin sedimentary sequences. After 3.0 Ga, however, the Kaapvaal and Pilbara Cratons, which formed at about 3.1–3.0 Ga, provided long-lived stable surfaces that were periodically flooded by shallow seas that hosted luxuriant biological communities and accumulated sequences of terrestrial to shallow-marine sediments that contain a still only slightly deformed and altered record of life and environments on extensive, low-relief, largely stable craton surfaces. Comparison of early life and environments based on sediments deposited in these two vastly different tectonic, magmatic, and depositional settings cannot be done without due consideration for the inherent differences in the resulting sedimentary and biological records.

sections.heading: 2. Archean environment and life 3.5–3.0 Ga
sections.text: Recent studies of the pre-3.0 Ga earth have outlined a considerably different picture of early Archean life and surface environments than had been suggested previously. For the purposes of this discussion, we divide the history of the 3.5–2.4 Ga interval into three main divisions: 3.5–3.0, 3.0–2.7, 2.7–2.4 Ga. Three principal aspects of the earth’s surface system will be considered for each time division: (1) the nature and amount of continental crust; (2) atmospheric composition and climate; (3) the nature of early life.

The preserved sedimentary record also provides no evidence for the existence of large continental blocks or cratons before 3.1 Ga. Such evidence could include (1) geochemical signatures of chemical sediments indicating that continental crust influenced the composition of sea water, (2) the presence of abundant and persistent detritus derived from differentiated igneous rocks, mainly coarse quartz and potassium feldspar, and (3) the formation of sedimentary basins on or around cratons and filled with thick sequences of craton-derived sediments. There are many small blocks of differentiated high-grade pre-3.1 Ga crust (Windley, 1995), but no evidence that these represent fragments of much larger pre-3.1 Ga cratons or associated craton cover or craton margin sedimentary sequences. The pre-3.1 Ga geologic record is dominated by altered and deformed volcanic and sedimentary “supracrustal” greenstone sequences. The best preserved and most studied include the Isua Supracrustal belt in west Greenland ∼3.8 Ga and the much better preserved Pilbara and Barberton greenstone belts, 3.5–3.2 Ga, in Western Australia and South Africa, respectively. In the following discussion, the geologic development of the BGB and Pilbara granite-greenstone terrains are reviewed with an aim of evaluating their implications for the evolution of the continental crust.

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Barberton granite-greenstone terrain (BGGT)
sections.text:
The Barberton greenstone belt (BGB), South Africa and Swaziland (Fig. 2), provides a good example of the development of these early greenstone sequences (Lowe and Byerly, in press). The BGB preserves a reasonably continuous record of volcanism and sedimentation from at least 3547 ± 3 Ma (Kröner et al., 1991) to about 3220 Ma (Lowe and Byerly, 1999, in press). Xenocrystic zircons 3702 ± 1 Ma in one 3450 ± 3 Ma TTG unit suggest the existence of even older differentiated intrusive or volcanic rocks in the area (Kröner et al., 1996). The greenstone record is dominated by rocks of the 10–12 km thick Onverwacht Group deposited from 3547 to ∼3260 Ma and the lower Fig Tree Group, ∼3260–3230 Ma. This sequence consists largely of mafic and ultramafic volcanic rocks, thinner felsic volcanic units, and mainly thin intervening sedimentary layers, now mostly cherts, representing silicified pyroclastic, chemical, and biogenic sediments (Lowe and Byerly, 1999). It formed through a series of mafic to felsic cycles over an interval of 300+ myr. Each cycle included eruption of a thick mafic to ultramafic volcanic succession that, toward the close of the cycle, was intruded at by TTG magmas and capped by comagmatic felsic volcanic rocks. sections.heading: 2.1.3. Crustal development before 3.0 Ga
sections.text:
None of the pre-3.1 Ga sequences studied to date reflects sedimentation on, adjacent to, or clearly influenced by craton-sized blocks of continental crust. The greenstone belts formed through the effusion of thick units of mafic to ultramafic lavas punctuated by the intrusion of TTG (tonalite-trondhjemite-granodiorite) plutons and eruption of comagmatic felsic volcanic rocks. Their development involved the formation of small, buoyant blocks of differentiated “continental” crust as TTG intrusive complexes and felsic volcanic units, which were locally exposed and onlapped by younger greenstone volcanic and sedimentary units and locally yielded quartzose and feldspathic sandstones through weathering and erosion. However, these were locally derived sedimentary units that were rapidly buried beneath younger greenstone-belt volcanic rocks. There is no evidence that they were amalgamated and thickened to form large cratonic blocks until about 3.1 Ga

In contrast, after 3.1 Ga in the BGGT and 3.0–2.9 Ga in the Pilbara, the 3.0–2.9 Ga Pongola and 2.8–2.7 Ga Fortescue Supergroups, respectively, were deposited on the eroded granite-greenstone cratonic roots. Both are only slightly deformed and reflect deposition of shallow-water to terrestrial, generally quartzand potassium-feldspar-rich clastic sediments sourced largely by cratonic basement with interbedded stromatolitic carbonates. These units unambiguously reflect sedimentation on thickened, stable cratonic blocks of continental crust. These and younger craton-cover sequences have provided the principal safe houses for the long-term storage and preservation of sedimentary rocks, including carbonates, and their records of climatic, atmospheric, and biological events.
Lowe (1992) has argued that the tectonic styles accompanying the major episodes of craton formation at 3.1–3.0, 2.75–2.6, 2.0–1.7 Ga, and the Neoproterozoic (1.0–0.6 Ga) show progressive changes that reflect the increasing activity and participation of large blocks of continental crust in the formation of new crustal blocks, suggesting an increasing inventory of large, rigid cratonic blocks over time. Finally, the chemical record of seawater composition indicates that the major change from a sea-floor/mantle to a continent buffered ocean did not occur until about 2.5 Ga (Veizer et al., 1982; Kamber and Webb, 2001).
We would suggest that the apparent conflict between the two current pictures of early crustal evolution reflects the contrasting data sets on which they are based. Arguments for abundant pre-3.1 Ga continental crust are based mainly on geochemical evidence for either the early segregation of large amounts of differentiated “continental” crust from the mantle or for early crustal thicknesses comparable to modern continental values. Much of the evidence against abundant early continental crust derives from studies of the influence of continental crust on sedimentary systems, which requires the existence of large, exposed cratons subject to weathering and erosion. Recent interpretations of the development of both the Pilbara Craton (Van Kranendonk et al., 2002) and the Barberton portion of the Kaapvaal Craton (Lowe and Byerly, in press) suggest that although TTG plutons, felsic volcanic rocks, and even more highly differentiated rocks were present in abundance as far back as at least 3.7 Ga, these rocks often lay buried beneath thick carapaces of mafic and ultramafic volcanic rocks and sediments, were not uplifted and exposed to weathering and erosion, other than locally and generally for short intervals of time, until about 3,230–3220 Ma, and were
Research 158 (2007) 177–197
not amalgamated and incorporated into large cratonic blocks until ∼3.1–2.95 Ga. Hence, large amounts of differentiated crustal components did form early in earth history, and formed major components of thick, pre3.1 granite-greenstone terrains, but large, uplifted and exposed continents and cratons that could significantly influence surface systems and the sedimentary record did not begin to form until about 3.1 Ga. Hence, it is felt that the stepwise growth curve best reflects the episodically increasing formation and influence of large cratonic blocks of continental crust on sedimentary and tectonic systems although smaller pieces of differentiated, continental crust may have formed and accumulated more continuously over geologic time.

sections.heading: 2.2. Atmospheric evolution and climate before 3.0 Ga
sections.text:
A range of interpretation exists for pre-3.0 Ga surface temperatures from very cold (Bada et al., 1994; Valley et al., 2002) to very hot (Knauth and Lowe, 1978, 2003; Schwartzman, 1999; Schwartzman and Lineweaver, 2004; Lowe and Tice, 2004). Knauth and Lowe (2003) have argued that the δ18O compositions of many cherts representing silicified sediments in the 3.5–3.2 Ga Barberton greenstone belt (BGB), South Africa, were set when disordered silica deposited from marine waters was converted to quartz at burial depths of <1 km. The isotopic composition of early diagenetic chert is influenced by the surface temperature at the time of quartz formation and the isotopic composition of the waters from which the quartz precipitated. In the least altered parts of the BGB sequence, these compositions have not been substantially changed by later diagenetic and metamorphic events or by slow, long-term exchange with subsurface waters (Knauth and Lowe, 2003). While the possibility of an early ocean substantially depleted in 18O cannot currently be excluded (e.g., Kasting et al., 2006), results to date suggest that the 18O composition of sea water has been essentially constant for most of geologic time (Muehlenbachs and Clayton, 1976; Gregory and Taylor, 1981; Muehlenbachs, 1998; Lecuyer and Allemand, 1999). Taken at face value, the least altered cherts analyzed indicate surface temperatures of 70 ± 15 ◦C at 3.5–3.2 Ga. High Archean surface temperatures are also suggested by studies of the silicon isotopic composition of cherts (Robert and Chaussidon, 2006).

Lowe (2007) noted a number of problems with this nalysis. slow exhumation, such that chemical weathering could proceed.” Even the depositional basin(s) in which the sediments were accumulating were undergoing uplift related to faulting along their margins (Heubeck and Lowe, 1994a,b) and were clearly receiving sediments from rapidly rising mountain belts through the activities of energetic, sand and gravel carrying rivers and streams. There would have been little opportunity for the deep weathering of such materials in the source area, within the transport system, or at the sites of deposition. The model system developed by Sleep and Hessler (2006) and clarified by Sleep and Hessler (2007) as not being aimed “to directly model the Moodies terrane,” is in fact totally unlike the surface system that prevailed during Moodies erosion, transport and sedimentation. Because Moodies sediments are the only ones discussed in this analysis, it is not clear which Archean sediments examined by these authors were deposited under the model conditions but lack the weathering and dissolution effects predicted by the model at high surface temperatures.
In fact, the Moodies Group shows three main characteristics suggesting formation in a highly aggressive weathering system: (1) Moodies conglomerates, although derived from a source terrain composed largely of TTG intrusive units and subordinate mafic and ultramafic volcanic rocks, are composed mainly of clasts of chert representing the most refractory but volumetrically minor components of the greenstone sequence (Heubeck and Lowe, 1999). There has been the almost total removal of more labile constituents, such as komatiitic and basaltic volcanic rocks. (2) Sandstones in the Moodies Group are composed largely of quartz (60–80%) and mostly monocrystalline quartz (40–60%), potassium feldspar (0–20%), and lithic grains (10–30%) (Heubeck and Lowe, 1999). These quartz contents represent a 5 to >10-fold increase in monocrystalline quartz over those of the potential source rocks. (3) Plagioclase, the major component of the TTG source rocks, comprises less than 2–3% of most Moodies sandstones. More labile sourcearea components, including ferromagnesian minerals, mafic and komatiitic volcanic rocks, and non-silicified sediments, representing perhaps 20% of the source rocks, form a minor part (<1%) of Moodies sediments or are absent altogether. Sediments of the Moodies Group display evidence of extreme weathering in spite of the fact they were derived from an orogenic source terrane that would have lacked vegetative cover and soils in which weathering could have progressed beyond simple loosening of grains from their surrounding matrix. We suggest that these weathering features are most consistent with the type of aggressive weathering that would

Sleep and Zahnle (2001) and Zahnle and Sleep (2002) have argued based on theoretical calculations and models of the early plate tectonic system that an early CO2 greenhouse would have rapidly dissipated as CO2 was deposited on oceanic crust in the form of carbonate and recycled back into the mantle. However, uncertainties about the nature of pre-3.0 Ga tectonic and sedimentary regimes, including the possibility that vertical rather than horizontal tectonics dominated crustal development until ∼3.2–3.1 Ga (Van Kranendonk et al., 2004), make such calculations premature.
O2 levels in the pre-3.0 Ga atmosphere have been explored based on mineral studies, paleosols, and redoxsensitive sediments, although much of the data in fact derive\from post-3.0 Ga rocks. With notable exceptions (e.g., Ohmoto, 1997, 2004), the prevailing view has been that Archean O2 levels were low, <10−4 bar, and that the surface environment was essentially anoxic (Walker et al., 1983; Holland, 1984; Rye and Holland, 1998; Rasmussen and Buick, 1999; Holland, 2002; and many others). Perhaps the most persuasive evidence for low O2 partial pressures before 3.0 Ga derives from sulfur isotopic studies (Fig. 3). Wide fluctuations in the Δ33S composition of pyrite, barite, and other sedimentary and early diagenetic sulfur-bearing minerals in pre-3.0 Ga sedimentary rocks result from mass-independent fractionation of sulfur isotopes in the upper atmosphere, reflecting extremely low-levels of atmospheric oxygen and the absence of an ozone layer in the Archean (Farquhar et al., 2000; Ono et al., 2003; Farquhar and Wing, 2003; Rumble, 2005).

sections.heading: 2.3. Life before 3.1 Ga
sections.text:
The geologic record of life or putative life before 3.1 Ga is widespread and abundant, but its interpretation, like aspects of the early surface environment discussed above, is controversial. The putative biological origins of carbonaceous matter (graphite), apatites, carbonate, and iron formation in the oldest metasedimentary rocks, the ∼3.8 Isua and Akilia supracrustal units in west Greenland, remain in doubt, and recent studies have shown that some and perhaps all of these materials may have originated through strictly abiotic metamorphic processes (van Zuilen et al., 2002, 2003; Lepland et al., 2002).
In the younger and better preserved 3.5–3.2 Ga greenstone belts, the available record includes (1) abundant carbonaceous matter preserved mainly in cherts and shales, (2) putative stromatolites, and (3) possible microfossils. Useful molecular biomarkers have not yet been identified in pre-3.0 Ga sedimentary rocks. Carbonaceous matter is abundant in many Archean cherts and most shows carbon isotopic fractionation consistent with fixation via autotrophic pathways, which has widely been taken as indicting a biological origin (Schidlowski et al., 1983; Schidlowski, 1988, 2000, 2001). However, recent studies have shown that simple organic compounds, including methane, ethane, and propane (Foustoukos and Seyfried, 2004), are produced abiotically in modern high-temperature sea floor hydrothermal systems associated with the alteration of ultramafic rocks (Horita and Berndt, 1999; Holm and Charlou, 2001). These compounds show isotopic fractionation of carbon similar to that resulting from biological processes (Horita and Berndt, 1999). Brasier et al. (2002, 2004, 2005) have used these results to argue that most if not all carbonaceous matter in Archean sediments should be regarded as being of abiological hydrothermal origin until “mutually supporting contextural, morphological and geochemical evidence for a bacterial rather than abiotic origin is forthcoming” (Brasier et al., 2004), although Brasier et al. (2006) have subsequently discussed the possible biogenicity of some pre-3.0 Ga structures. This argument ignores the fact that that there is as yet no known mechanism that does not involve organisms for transforming the simple volatile organic compounds that can be produced within hydrothermal systems into the more complex solid organic matter and structures represented by the carbonaceous matter in these ancient sequences (Fig. 2 and Tice and Lowe, 2006b). While studies of Tice and Lowe (2004, 2006a,b) have provided reasonably solid environmental, geochemical, and morphological evidence for the biological origins of carbonaceous matter in these sequences, the actual origins of specific microfossil-like structures remain controversial.

sections.heading: 3.1. Continental crust 3.0–2.7 Ga
sections.text: Based on an inventory of existing Precambrian continental crust, Lowe (1992) estimated that about 10% of the present-day Precambrian continental crust formed 3.2–3.0 Ga (Fig. 1). This estimate is generally consistent with similar estimates of continental growth rates by Veizer and Jansen (1979, 1985) and others. The probable loss of early crust during later recycling events makes this a minimum estimate. This early crust, including the present-day Kaapvaal Craton, formed 3.2–3.1 Ga by the tectonic amalgamation and thickening of the 3.55–3.2 Ga greenstone terranes and thickening and stabilization by intra-crustal melting and intrusion of large volumes of granitic magmas at about 3.1 Ga. The Pilbara Craton shows a generally similar geologic development, although greenstone activity continued to about 3.0 Ga and crustal formation was not complete until 3.0–2.9 Ga. Subsequent erosion of the upper ∼5 km of these newly formed crustal blocks produced surfaces upon which initial alluvial and shallow-marine, craton-cover sediments were deposited, including sediments of the 3.0–2.8 Ga Pongola Supergroup in South Africa and the 2.8–2.7 Ga Fortescue Supergroup, Western Australia. These are the oldest known craton cover sediments.

sections.heading: 3.2. Atmospheric evolution and climate 3.0–2.7 Ga
sections.text:
Collapse of the pre-3.2 Ga greenhouse and the end of what may have been a prolonged early phase of biological evolution at high temperatures appears to have been brought about by the formation of the first cratons between 3.1 and 2.9 Ga (Lowe and Tice, 2004) (Fig. 6).
These large, initially high-standing blocks of juvenile crust were subject to long-term weathering and erosion between 3.2 and 2.8 Ga, gradually lowering atmospheric CO2 (Carver and Vardavas, 1994, 1995; Lowe, 1994b; Lowe and Tice, 2004). The culmination of climate collapse may have been a period of glaciation recorded in the ∼2.9 Ga Mozaan Group of the Pongola Supergroup and correlative strata in the Witwatersrand Supergroup in South Africa (Wiebols, 1955; von Brunn and Gold, 1993; Young et al., 1998; Nhleko, 2004). Similar but somewhat older diamictites are present in the 3.0 Ga Nsuze Group of the Pongola Supergroup. These units may represent even older glacial deposits, although they have not been studied in any detail. While these putative glacial deposits have yet to be fully explored, the 2.9 Ga units represent a widespread, correlative event of diamictite formation within otherwise shallow marine and alluvial settings. The diamictites are thick, in the case of the upper part of the Pongola Supergroup up to 100 m, continuous over wide areas, and generally not associated with other features that might indicate a debris-flow origin. Young et al. (1998) report varves associated with the upper Pongola diamictites. Based on examination of both Pongola and Witwatersrand diamictites and associated units in the field and core, the authors concur that these deposits most likely record an interval of glaciation and cold-climate conditions. Like many other major glaciations, these early Late Archean glaciations may have been episodic and separated by intervals of less extreme climatic conditions.
The deposition of organic carbon with δ13C values of −40‰ to −60‰ at 2.8–2.7 Ga (Schidlowski et al., 1983; Rye and Holland, 1998) has been interpreted to reflect a gradual rise in the atmospheric CH4/CO2 ratio until at ∼2.9–2.8 Ga it reached ∼1 (Pavlov et al., 2001). It cannot yet be determined whether cyanobacteria and oxygenic photosynthesis actually evolved 3.0–2.7 Ga, as suggested by some (e.g., Hayes, 1983), or whether decreasing climatic temperatures allowed previously struggling cyanobacterial groups that evolved before 3.0 Ga to bloom and expand as the climate became more hospitable. The Cambrian explosion of metazoan groups was probably preceded by a prolonged interval of metazoan evolution in which the major taxa evolved and differentiated and their appearance in the fossil record more reflects an adaptation to environmental conditions and the evolution of hard parts than the actual point in time at which the taxa evolved (Knoll and Carroll, 1999). A similarly long evolutionary history may have characterized cyanobacteria before their earliest known appearance in the geologic record at 3.0 Ga as stromatolites or 2.7 Ga as molecular biomarkers.

sections.heading: 4.1. Continental crust 2.7–2.4 Ga
sections.text: The period from about 2.75 to 2.65 Ga represents perhaps the most significant episode of new continental crust formation and reworking of older continental crust in earth history (Taylor and McLennan, 1985, 1995; McLennan and Taylor, 1991; Lowe, 1994b; Condie, 1995; Rey et al., 2003; and many others). The formation and amalgamation of greenstone belts through the development and collapse of magmatic arcs during this period led to the generation of at least 50% of the Precambrian continental crust that exists today (Fig. 1). Between about 2.6 and 2.4 Ga, this new crust was deeply eroded and after about 2.4 Ga, it became the site for the deposition of new craton cover sediments.

sections.heading: 4.2. Atmospheric evolution and climate 2.7–2.4 Ga
sections.text:
Less attention has focused specifically on the climate of the 2.7–2.4 Ga interval than on either the pre-2.7
Research 158 (2007) 177–197
or post-2.4 Ga intervals. After 2.4 Ga, perhaps the most striking sedimentary sequences are widespread glaciogenic units deposited on the newly formed continental blocks (Young, 1991; Bekker et al., 2001). This interval of climatic instability and glaciation between about 2.45 and 2.2 Ga, has been interpreted to reflect removal of CO2 from the atmosphere as a consequence of Neoarchean continental growth and dynamics (Carver and Vardavas, 1994, 1995; Bekker et al., 2001; Lindsay and Brasier, 2002).
The climatic regime 2.7–2.5 is more problematic. The anomalously light δ13C values of organic carbon disappear at about 2.7 Ga and do not persist into the latest Neoarchean, suggesting either that atmospheric CH4/CO2 ratio returned to <1 and aerosol production ceased or that isotopically light methane aerosols were overwhelmed by isotopically “normal” biological organic carbon. However, high magnitude Δ33S values, between −2.7‰ and +8.7‰, return in post2.7 Ga rocks (Farquhar et al., 2000; Ono et al., 2003). These results suggest that once again O2 levels in the atmosphere were extremely low and remained so until past the end of the Archean (Farquhar et al., 2000; Farquhar and Wing, 2003; Ono et al., 2003; Rumble, 2005).
We would suggest that as relief on the continental blocks that formed 3.2–2.9 Ga was reduced by erosion and the basement surfaces covered by sediments, recycling of CO2 via tectonic processes may have eventually outstripped CO2 removal by weathering and atmospheric CO2 levels began to rise. This could have both decreased the CH4/CO2 ratio to the point that CH4/CO2 1, which would have turned off the generation of methane haze at about 2.7 Ga. In addition, widespread volcanism 2.75–2.65 Ga associated with the Neoarchean greenstone belt activity may have been accompanied by the release of large amounts of new and recycled CO2. We suggest that by about 2.7 Ga, surface temperatures had again increased to >60 ◦C due to re-establishment of an effective CO2 and CH4 greenhouse (Fig. 6). CH4 would have increased in abundance as O2 production by cyanobacteria declined as temperatures rose >60 ◦C. These warm temperatures apparently persisted, perhaps with significant fluctuations, until ∼2.5 Ga, when erosion of the newly formed Neoarchean cratons began to strip CO2 from the atmosphere.

. Discussion
.1. Archean evolutionary scenario
1) From >3.5 to 3.2 Ga, the available rock record suggests that the earth’s surface was dominated by a basaltic and komatiitic crust. Although there were probably many blocks of more buoyant differen-
Research 158 (2007) 177–197 189
tiated crust, especially TTG intrusive complexes and a few microcontinental remnants of still older crust, all were apparently small and most lay buried beneath thick sections of greenstone belt volcanic rocks until about 3.3–3.2 Ga. Most of the greenstone sequences show evidence for submarine deposition and only local uplift and significant elevation of the rock surfaces above sea level. As a result of the absence of large, high-standing continental blocks, weathering was a minor sink for CO2 and surface temperatures were hot, maintained between 73 and 60 ◦C by a CO2 and CH4 greenhouse within which CH4/CO2 1. Within this temperature range, photosynthesis is possible but all modern photosynthetic organisms living at these temperatures are poorly motile. Microbial mats are widely preserved within sediments deposited within the photic zone during this time, probably representing anoxygenic photoautotrophs (Tice and Lowe, 2004, 2006a,b). Large three-dimensional stromatolites are absent. Cyanobacteria, if they had evolved, were minor players in the biological community and any oxygen they may have produced was consumed locally and did not accumulate in the atmosphere. Extremely low atmospheric O2 levels were associated with massindependent fractionation of sulfur, characterized by wide fluctuations in Δ33S of sedimentary barite and pyrite. (2) The interval 3.2–3.0 or 2.9 Ga is poorly represented by sedimentary units, but was an interval of continental crust formation: at least 10% of the preserved Precambrian continental crust formed at this time, including the Kaapvaal and Pilbara Cratons (Lowe, 1992). This new crust was high standing and subjected to deep, long-term weathering and erosion, which resulted in the stripping of CO2 from the atmosphere. (3) From 3.0 to 2.7 Ga CO2 loss through weathering, CH4 loss through the formation of methane haze as CO2/CH4 dropped to ∼1, and possibly antigreenhouse cooling due to methane haze formation collectively resulted in climate collapse and glaciation by 2.9 Ga and perhaps as early as 3.0 Ga. Cyanobacteria, whether they had evolved at this time or under the earlier hot climate, displaced hightemperature anoxygenic photoautotrophs within microbial communities. Their remains are represented by the first large, morphologically modern
stromatolites in rocks about 3.0 Ga in the Nsuze Group of the Pongola Supergroup. The oxygen produced by cyanobacteria probably scrubbed remaining methane from the atmosphere and eventu-

ally accumulated to levels sufficient to reduce mass independent fractionation. Δ33S values show only narrow departures from 0 to 3.0–2.8 Ga. These levels may have been substantially below those necessary for depletion of the reservoir of reduced iron in the deep ocean, oxidation of surface mineral grains, and the formation of red beds, effects that appear during more widespread atmospheric oxygenation in Proterozoic time. (4) 2.7–2.4 Ga. As the continental blocks that had formed 3.2–2.9 Ga were reduced by erosion and increasingly covered with sediments after about 2.8 Ga, removal of atmospheric CO2 by weathering slowed and atmospheric gain through recycling may have resulted in rising CO2 levels. Additional large influxes of CO2 may also have accompanied massive greenstone belt volcanism 2.75–2.65 Ga. At about 2.7 Ga, rising atmospheric CO2 provided sufficient greenhouse warming that the surface temperature again surpassed 60 ◦C, suppressing cyanobacterial growth and reducing the flux of O2 to the atmosphere, perhaps allowing methane levels to rise through the increased activities of methanogens under the higher temperature surface regime. MIF resumed in the upper atmosphere. These conditions persisted to about 2.45 Ga by which time weathering of the newly formed Neoarchean continental crust triggered a second major greenhouse collapse resulting in glaciation, the re-emergence of cyanobacteria, and eventual permanent oxygenation of the earth’s atmosphere.
While this series of events is plausible given our current knowledge of the Archean geologic record, more speculative series of events may also be permissible. For instance, if 2-methylhopanes and steranes in 2.7 Ga sediments do not reflect the presence of cyanobacteria and oxygen-dependent eukaryotes, respectively, then geological signals in the period 3.0–2.7 Ga may reflect only the effects of a hydrocarbon haze and associated antigreenhouse cooling. In this scenario, decreased sulfur mass-independent fractionation might reflect UV shielding of volcanogenic SO2 by a hydrocarbon haze generated in a low CO2/CH4 atmosphere. Associated cooling might have increased the motility of anoxygenic photosynthetic organisms, potentially allowing these microbes rather than cyanobacteria to construct preserved 3.0–2.7 Ga three-dimensional stromatolites. Subsequent tectonic return of sequestered CO2 would have reversed these trends. At present, however, we consider that this scenario is less likely than that proposed here.

sections.heading: 5.2. CO2 versus CH4 as the principal greenhouse gas
sections.text:
It has been suggested that the Archean atmosphere may have had methane as the principal greenhouse gas (Kasting, 2004, 2005). If so, the collapse of an early methane-mediated greenhouse could have been driven after 3.0 Ga by the rise in atmospheric oxygen due to the evolution or expansion of cyanobacteria, as has been proposed for the Paleoproterozoic glaciations (Kasting et al., 1983, 2001; Pavlov et al., 2000; Kopp et al., 2005). While a possible alternative to the scenario presented here, the methane-dominant scenario provides no clear explanation of the apparent coupling of continental crust formation and atmospheric evolution that occurred not only 3.2–2.9 Ga, but also following the major crust-forming events in the Neoarchean and Neoproterozoic (Bekker et al., 2001). The three known major glaciations of the Precambrian each follow a major phase of continental crust formation (Lowe, 1992, 1994b), suggesting a direct relationship. It is not clear how continental crust formation would have consistently impacted methane abundance, which does not participate directly in rock weathering, but weathering of large, high-standing, newly formed blocks of continental crust would clearly have severely reduced atmospheric CO2.
In addition, it is difficult to account for the return of MIF and implied decline in atmospheric oxygen in the Neoarchean at about 2.7 Ga just through fluctuations in atmospheric methane. In the absence of major surface temperature variations unrelated to methane abundance, once cyanobacteria had evolved and populated marine environments 3.0–2.7 Ga, low methane levels should have been maintained simply through continuing oxygenic photosynthesis. However, if CO2 was in fact the major greenhouse gas at this time, gradual lowering of the 3.1-Ga continental blocks by weathering and erosion and progressive burial of these blocks beneath craton-cover sediments would have been resulted in reduced rates of CO2 removal. Eventually, the output of CO2 through tectonic recycling and new greenstone belt volcanism would have surpassed the loss through weathering and CO2 levels in the atmosphere and surface temperatures could have returned to high, pre-3.0 Ga levels.
We therefore suggest that high levels of CO2 could have provided the greenhouse effects implied by early hot temperatures, the enhanced weathering rates at 3.2 Ga suggested by sandstone compositions, and elevated CO2 levels required for nahcolite sedimentation on the pre-3.2 Ga earth. The rarity of well-developed microbial mats and larger, well-formed three-dimensional stromatolites in rocks older than 3.0 Ga may reflect the dominance of thin biofilms composed of anoxygenic photosynthetic microbes on submarine surfaces within the euphotic zone, as interpreted by Tice and Lowe (2006a). These organisms were poorly motile and not able under most circumstances to construct complex or large threedimensional stromatolites.
Climatic collapse 3.0–2.9 Ga would have taken surface temperatures below 60 ◦C providing surface environments favorable to the growth of thick microbial mats constructed by highly motile filamentous oxygenic photosynthetic cyanobacteria. Lower temperatures and broad expanses of eroded craton surfaces covered by shallow seas at this time would have provided the first long-lived surface environments within which known filamentous cyanobacteria could have thrived. Development of communities dominated by these microbes, either by their evolution and first appearance or by the spread of habitats in which they could out-compete other microbes 3.0–2.7 Ga, would have allowed construction of the first morphologically modern stromatolites, which in fact appear in the geologic record at 3.0 Ga. The resulting output of O2 would have eventually depleted methane as an atmospheric gas (Fig. 6), allowing the accumulation of atmospheric O2 and decreased MIF 3.0–2.7 Ga (Fig. 3).

Subsequent rising CO2 levels at about 2.7 Ga would have returned the earth’s surface to conditions like those prevailing in hot springs and their run-out systems above 60 ◦C. However, the presence of sporadic stromatolites within the 2.7–2.5 Ga interval suggests that temperatures may have fluctuated about 60 ◦C, with a more permanent drop to below 60 ◦C occurring only during the latest Archean or early Paleoproterozoic (Fig. 6).

sections.heading: 6. Later Precambrian events
sections.text:
Tectonic, climatic, and biological events 3.2–2.7 Ga are remarkably comparable to those of the Neoarchean and earliest Proterozoic, 2.7–2.2 Ga (Fig. 10). As noted above a greater area/volume of continental crust was formed in the Neoarchean, between about 2.75 and 2.60 Ga, than during any other interval of earth history. This interval of crust formation was followed by weathering and erosion of this newly formed crust that culminated in climatic instability and glaciation between about 2.45 and 2.2 Ga. This interval of climatic instability and glaciation probably reflected removal of CO2 from the atmosphere (Carver and Vardavas, 1994, 1995; Bekker et al., 2001). This carbonate sedimentation coupled with deep-ocean accumulation of organic carbon would have provided means of long-term sequestration of atmospheric CO2, leading to a permanent reduction of post-Archean atmospheric CO2 levels. The initial stage of the Paleoproterozoic cycle of atmospheric oxygenation is recorded in sediments perhaps as old as 2.4 Ga (Farquhar et al., 2000) and certainly by 2.2–2.1 Ga (Karhu and Holland, 1996). This suggests that the final ascendance of more moderate-temperature oxygenic photosynthetic microbes, probably cyanobacteria, within marine microbial communities may have accompanied cooling and climate collapse during the latest Archean and earliest Paleoproterozoic.

. Conclusions
The present study suggests a close link between rustal, atmospheric, climatic, and biological evolution .5–2.4 Ga. Previous studies have emphasized such a elationship between Precambrian tectonics, climatic xcursions, and sedimentation and more specifically etween Proterozoic tectonics, isotopic excursions, and nstability in the surface carbon cycle (Des Marais, 994; Bekker et al., 2001) and biological evolution Lindsay and Brasier, 2002). We argue here that simlar cycles of tectonic, climatic, and biological change xtend back to at least 3.2 Ga. The earliest geoogic record appears to document a hot young earth, 0 ± 15 ◦C at 3.5–3.2 Ga. Initial crust-forming events .2–2.9 Ga led to increased subaerial weathering, declinng atmospheric levels of CO and CH , and, as a 2 4 esult, decreasing surface temperatures and eventually laciation ∼3.0–2.9 Ga. Decreased surface temperatures nfluenced long-term biological evolution 3.0–2.7 Ga y providing a surface environment in which oxygenic

photosynthetic microbes, probably cyanobacteria, could survive and prosper at the expense of more extreme thermophiles, including methanogens, which had dominated surface systems before 3.0 Ga. Little long-term carbonate sequestration through sedimentation occurred at this time because of the small overall surface area of stable cratonic blocks formed 3.1–3.0 Ga. As erosion of the early continents slowed, tectonic recycling, and renewed greenstone volcanism, perhaps related to continental breakup and superplume events, returned most CO2 to the atmosphere and temperatures began to rise. During the early Neoarchean ∼2.7 Ga, surface temperatures may have fluctuated but commonly lay above 60 ◦C. The formation of new large blocks of continental crust in the Neoarchean ∼2.6 Ga and ensuing weathering of this new crust once again drove atmospheric CO2 decline, culminating in glaciation 2.45–2.2 Ga. The return of cooler climates <2.5 Ga would have allowed the final ascendancy of the cyanobacteria as the dominant marine microbes, reflected in the saturation of early O2 sinks and oxygenation of the atmosphere perhaps as early as 2.4 Ga but certainly by ∼2.2–2.1 Ga. Permanent sequestration of CO2 as carbonate deposits on the older 3.2–3.0 Ga crustal blocks ∼2.6–2.4 Ga insured that atmospheric CO2 levels and surface temperatures never returned to earlier high levels.
Tectonic, climatic, and biological events 3.5–2.7 and 2.75–2.2 Ga are remarkably parallel to Neoproterozoic events 1.0–0.5 Ga, which culminated in the emergence of the metazoans. These ∼500 myr-long cycles of crust formation and weathering, atmospheric and climatic instability, and biological innovation suggest that evolution of the earth’s interior has exerted a fundamental control on environmental and biological evolution at the earth’s surface. The present study suggests that this control is exerted mainly through crustal influence on atmospheric CO2 level, which influences surface temperature and thence biological evolution.

abstractText: This paper presents a speculative scenario for the evolution of the earth’s surface environment and biological community 3.5–2.4 Ga based on the geologic record and its interpretation. Available geologic evidence suggests that the earth’s climate before 3.2 Ga was hot, probably 60–73 ◦C, as a result of a CO2 and CH4 greenhouse. The early biological community was probably dominated by anoxygenic photosynthetic thermophiles. Cyanobacteria, if they evolved before 3.1 Ga, would have struggled to survive at such high temperatures. As a result, the atmosphere contained extremely low levels of O2 and Δ33S shows wide departures from 0 indicating mass independent fractionation of S isotopes in the upper atmosphere. This hot early climate collapsed 3.1–3.0 Ga due to growth of large new blocks of continental crust (cratons), the weathering of which resulted in the depletion of atmospheric CO2 and eventual drawdown of CH4 due to formation and rainout of methane aerosols. Cooling may have culminated in glaciation about 3.0–2.9 Ga. This climatic catastrophe and attendant changes in atmospheric composition drove a major biological revolution 3.0–2.7 Ga characterized by the emergence of new low-temperature taxa, including cyanobacteria, and their spread throughout surface environments at the expense of extreme thermophiles, including methanogens. During a period of general tectonic stability, 3.0–2.7 Ga, the earth’s surface was characterized by overall clement conditions with temperatures <60 ◦C, abundant cyanobacteria and the formation of associated three-dimensional stromatolites, and a mild oxygenation of the atmosphere and attendant reduction in mass independent fractionation. As the cratons that had formed 3.1–3.0 Ga were eroded down and gradually covered by sediments, tectonic recycling and a burst of new greenstone-belt volcanism began to increase atmospheric CO2 after 2.75 Ga and by 2.7 Ga surface temperatures had returned to >60 ◦C. Cyanobacteria were again suppressed, O2 production waned, and atmospheric mass independent fractionation is again indicated by extreme variations in Δ33S. These conditions persisted, perhaps intermittently, until about 2.5–2.4 Ga, when weathering and erosion of vast new blocks of continental crust formed about 2.65–2.6 Ga caused the second, and probably last collapse of a >60 ◦C surface climate. Broad tectonic, climatic, and biological events 3.5–2.9 Ga are remarkably parallel to those of the Late Archean and Paleoproterozoic 2.75–2.2 Ga and Neoproterozoic 1.0–0.50 Ga. These ∼500-myr long cycles of greenstone volcanism and crustal generation; climatic and atmospheric instability; and biological innovation reflect the long-term interaction of the tectonic, atmospheric, climatic, and biological components of the earth’s surface system. They suggest that the evolution of the earth’s interior, expressed through its control on the formation of large blocks of continental crust, has influenced atmospheric composition and climate which in turn have provided a fundamental control on the timing and directions of biological evolution throughout earth history. © 2007 Elsevier B.V.
